title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement:
\label{binomial-representation} Let $k$ be a positive integer. We have
(a)  \[ \label{positive} \tau_k(n+1)=\sum_{\substack{n=a_1^{f_1}\cdots a_r^{f_r}; f_i\leq k.}}(-1)^{f_1+\cdots f_r}{k\choose{f_1}}\cdots {k\choose{f_r}}, \]
(b)  \[ \label{negative} \tau_{-k}(n+1)=\sum_{\substack{n=a_1^{f_1}\cdots a_r^{f_r}}}{f_1+k-1\choose{k-1}}\cdots {f_r+k-1\choose{k-1}}. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: \label{parity-gen} Let $k$ be a positive integer. Let $A=\{a\in\mathbb N:a\leq k, {{k}\choose{a}}\equiv 1\pmod{2}\}$. We have  \[ \tau_k(n+1)\equiv F_A(n)\pmod{2}. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: \label{parityoftau} Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ R_4(n)\equiv\begin{cases}1\pmod{2}&{\text { if }n=\frac{m(m+1)}{2}}; 0\pmod{2}&{\text{ otherwise}}. \end{cases} \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: For every positive integer $s$, we have  \[ R_{2^s}(n)\equiv\tau_{2^s-1}(n+1)\pmod 2. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: \label{taumodulo3} Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ \tau(n+1)\equiv\begin{cases} R_9\left(\frac{n}{3}\right)\pmod 3&\text{ if $3\mid n$}; 0\pmod 3&\text{ otherwise}. \end{cases} \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: \label{taumodulo5} Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ \tau(n+1)\equiv R_{25}(n)\pmod{5}. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: \label{taumodulo7} Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ \tau(n+1)\equiv \sum_{n=\frac{m(m+1)}{2}+7\frac{r(r+1)}{2}}(-1)^{m+r}(2m+1)(2r+1)\pmod{7}. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ \tau(n+1)\equiv\sum_{n=\frac{3l^2\pm l}{2}+\frac{3m^2\pm m}{2}+11\frac{3s^2\pm s}{2}+11\frac{3r^2\pm r}{2}}(-1)^{l+m+s+r}\pmod{11}. \]

title: Congruences Relating Regular Partition Functions, a Genearalised Tau   Function and Partition Function Weighted Composition Sums
theorem_statement: Let $n$ be a positive integer. We have  \[ \tau(n+1)\equiv \sum_{n=13\times\frac{3r^2\pm r}{2}+s}(-1)^r\tau_{11}(s)\pmod{13}. \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement:
\label{Theorem1} Suppose that $F(	au) = \sum_{l=-m}^{\infty} c_F^+(l)q^l = q^{-m} + O(q^{-m+1})$ is a weight $2 - k$ harmonic Maass weak eigenform with real Fourier coefficients with shadow $G(	au) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a(n)q^n$. Then the following are true. 
oindent
(1) For every $n \geq 2$, we have that  \[ H_n(F;	au) := \Delta(	au)^{b(k - 2)} \widetilde{E}_{k-2}(	au) \cdot \left( n^{k-1} F(	au) \ | \ T_{2-k}(n) - a(n)F(	au) ight) \]  is a weakly holomorphic function on $\SL_2(\Z)$, where  \[ b(k):= egin{cases} \lfloor k/12floor \ \ \ \ \ &{	ext {if}}\ k
ot \equiv 2\pmod{12}, \lfloor k/12floor -1 \ \ \ \ \ &{	ext {if}}\ k\equiv 2\pmod{12}. \end{cases} \]  
oindent
(2) For every $n \geq 2$, there exists a monic polynomial $P_n(F;x) \in \R[x]$ of degree $mn - b(k - 2)$ for which  \[ P_n(F;j(	au)) = H_n(F;	au). \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{Theorem2} Assuming the notations and hypotheses of Theorem~\ref{Theorem1}, if $n \geq 7$ satisfies  \[ C_F n^{k-1} e^{-\pi n\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}} < 1, \]  then $P_n(F;x)$ has $mn - b(k - 2)$ distinct zeros in $[0,1728]$, where  \[ C_F := \frac{1}{4}\max \left\{80m^{k-1}\sum_{l=1}^{m} \abs{c_F^+(-l)}, 1\right\} \]  is a constant depending only on $F$.

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement:
\label{MaassPoincare} Assuming the hypotheses above, the following are true. \noindent
(1) We have  \[ \xi_{2-k}(\cF_{2-k,-l}) = (-1)^{k+1} \frac{(4\pi l)^{k-1}}{\Gamma(k-1)} \cP_{k,l}. \]  \noindent
(2) We have that $\cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau)$ is a weight $2-k$ harmonic Maass form on $\SL_2(\Z)$, with  \[ \cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau) = \cF_{2-k,-l}^+(\tau) + \cF_{2-k,-l}^-(\tau), \]  where $\cF_{2-k,-l}^+(\tau)$ (resp. $\cF_{2-k,-l}^-(\tau)$) is its holomorphic part (resp. nonholomorphic part). \smallskip \noindent
(3) The holomorphic part of $\cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau)$ has Fourier expansion  \[ \cF_{2-k,-l}^+(\tau)= q^{-l} - \frac{(2\pi i)^k l^{k-1}}{\Gamma(k)}\sum_{c > 0} \frac{K_{2-k}(l,0;c)}{c^k} + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c^+_{2-k,-l}(n)q^n, \]  where for positive integers $n$ we have  \[ c_{2-k,-l}^+(n) = 2\pi i^{2-k} \left(\frac{l}{n}\right)^{\frac{k-1}{2}} \sum_{c > 0} \frac{K_{2-k}(l,n;c)}{c} \cdot I_{k-1}\left(\frac{4\pi\sqrt{ln}}{c}\right). \]  \smallskip \noindent
(4) The nonholomorphic part of $\cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau)$ has Fourier expansion  \[ \cF_{2-k,-l}^-(\tau) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c_{2-k,-l}^-(-n)\Gamma(1 - k, 4\pi n v)q^{-n}, \]  where for positive integers $n$ we have  \[ c_{2-k,-l}^-(-n) = 2\pi i^{2-k} \left(\frac{l}{n}\right)^{\frac{k-1}{2}} \sum_{c > 0} \frac{K_{2-k}(l,-n;c)}{c} \cdot J_{k-1}\left(\frac{4\pi\sqrt{l n}}{c}\right). \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement:
\label{PoincareBasis} Assuming the notation and hypotheses above, the following are true. \noindent
(1) Every cusp form of weight $k$ is a linear combination of Poincar\'e series $\cP_{k,l}(\tau)$ with $l \geq 1$. \noindent
(2) Every harmonic Maass form of weight $2-k$ is a linear combination of Poincar\'e series $\cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau)$ with $l \geq 1$. In particular, if $F(\tau) = \sum_{l=-m}^{\infty} c_F^+(l)q^l$, then  \[ F(\tau) = \sum_{l=1}^{m} c_F^+(-l) \cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau). \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: Assuming the notation and hypotheses above, we have, for all $n \geq 1$,  \[ \cF_{2-k,-l}(\tau) \ | \ T_{2-k}(n) = \sum_{d \mid (l,n)} \left( \frac{n}{d} \right)^{1-k} \cF_{2-k,-\frac{ln}{d^2}}(\tau). \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{QBound} If $l \geq 1$ and $\theta \in [\frac{\pi}{3},\frac{\pi}{2}]$, then we have  \[ \abs{Q_{2-k,-l}(\theta)} \leq e^{2\pi l \sin \theta} + 8le^{\pi l \sin \theta} + 1.008 \times 10^{8}l^{k-1}. \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{PBound} For all $l \geq 1$ and $\theta \in [\frac{\pi}{3},\frac{\pi}{2}]$, we have  \[ \abs{\cF_{2-k,-l}(e^{i\theta})} \leq 4e^{2\pi l \sin \theta} + 1.008 \times 10^8 l^{k-1}. \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{RBound} For all $n \geq 2$ and $\theta \in [\frac{\pi}{3},\frac{\pi}{2}]$, we have  \[ \abs{R_n(F;\theta)} \leq\left( 8m^{k-2}n^{\frac{k}{2}}e^{\pi(2m - 1)n\sin \theta} + 2.016 \times 10^8 (mn)^{k-1}\right) \sum_{l=1}^{m } \abs{c_F^+(-l)} \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{QRBound} If $n \geq 7$ is such that  \[ C_F n^{k-1}e^{-\pi n \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}} < 1, \]  then we have  \[ \abs{e^{\frac{2-k}{2}i\theta}e^{-2\pi mn \sin \theta}H_n^\ast(F;e^{i\theta}) - f_{mn}(\theta)} < 2. \]

title: Zeros of Hecke polynomials arising from weak eigenforms
theorem_statement: \label{Corollary3} Assuming the notation and hypotheses of Theorem~\ref{Theorem1}, then for sufficiently large $n$, we have that the zeros of $P_n(F;x)$ are distinct and equidistributed in the interval $[0, 1728]$.

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:twin_cyclics} There exist infinitely many cyclic integers \(c\in\mathcal{C}\) such that \(c+2\in\mathcal{C}\).

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:legendre_cyclics} For every \(n\in\mathbb{N}\), there exists \(c\in\mathcal{C}\) with \(n^2<c<(n+1)^2\).

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:squares} As $n\to\infty$, \[ C\big((n+1)^2\big) - C(n^2) \sim \frac{2n}{e^{\gamma}\,\log_3 n}\left(1-\frac{\gamma}{\log_3 n}\right). \]

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:near_square_cyclics} Infinitely many \(n\in\mathbb{N}\) satisfy \(n^2+1\in\mathcal{C}\).

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:k_fold_oppermann_for_primes} For every $k\in\mathbb{N}$ there exists $N(k)$ such that for all $n>N(k)$, both intervals $[n^2-n,n^2]$ and $[n^2,n^2+n]$ contain at least $k$ primes.

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:k_fold_oppermann_for_cyclics} For every $k\in \mathbb{N}$ there exists $N(k)$ such that for all $n>N(k)$, both intervals $[n^2-n,n^2]$ and $[n^2,n^2+n]$ contain at least $k$ cyclic integers.

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:twin_cyclics_between_consecutive_cubes} At least two twin cyclic pairs between \(n^3\) and \((n+1)^3\); more generally, at least k beyond a threshold.

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:infinitely_many_sg_cyclics} There are infinitely many \(c\in\mathcal{C}\) with \(2c+1\in\mathcal{C}\).

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:sg_cyclics_modulo_3} As the number of SG cyclics grows, the limiting fractions congruent to 1 and 3 mod 3 are equal.

title: Conjectures About Cyclic Numbers: Resolutions and Counterexamples
theorem_statement: \label{thm:firoozbakht_cyclics_3} For each \(k\) there exists \(N(k)\) such that for all \(n>N(k)\), \(c_n^{1/(n+k)}>c_{n+1}^{1/(n+k+1)}\).

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: There is an algorithm that, given a quadratic irrational $\alpha$ with $0 < \alpha < 1$, constructs a finite automaton that takes as input pairs $(m,n)$, represented in the Ostrowski $\alpha$-numeration system, and accepts if and only if the $m \times n$ blocks of the Sturmian matrix ${\cal A}_{\alpha}$ are balanced. \label{main}

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: Assume $m \leq n$ and let the Zeckendorf expansion of $m$ (resp., $n$) be $F_{a_1} + \dots + F_{a_k}$ (resp., $ F_{b_1} + \dots + F_{b_\ell}$) for $a_1 > \cdots >a_k$ and $b_1 > \cdots > b_\ell$. Then $(m,n)$ is accepted by {\tt bal} if and only if at least one of the following cases holds: ((a)) $m = 0$ or $m = 1$; ((b)) $m = F_{a_1}$ and $a_1 \notin \{b_1, \ldots, b_\ell\}$ and for $b_j > a_1 > b_{j+1}$ the indices $a_1$ and $b_j$ have the same parity; ((c)) $m = F_{a_1}$ and $a_1 \in \{b_1, \ldots, b_\ell\}$; ((d)) $a_1 = b_\ell$, (i.e., the largest Fibonacci number in the representation of $m$ is the smallest Fibonacci number in the representation of $n$) and $b_\ell$ and $b_{\ell-1}$ have distinct parities; ((e)) $a_1 < b_\ell$ (i.e., the largest Fibonacci number in the representation of $m$ is smaller than the smallest Fibonacci number in the representation of $n$).

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: Consider the word rectangles formed from the Fibonacci word $\bf f$ with the indexing $f_0 f_1 f_2 \cdots = 0100$. The number of distinct values of $T(i,m,n)$, taken over all $i$, for $m = n = F_{3k}/2$, is at least $k+1$. \label{bnd}

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: If $(a_i)_{i \geq 0}$ is a Sturmian word corresponding to the irrational number $\alpha$, then in the matrix ${\cal A}_\alpha = (a_{i,j})_{i,j\geq 0}$ the $m \times n$ blocks are balanced if and only if the sequence $\Delta(i,m,n)$ has no blocks of the form $1,0,0,\ldots, 0,1$ or $-1,0,0,\ldots,0, -1$. \label{lemma1}

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: Let $n \geq 2$. ((a)) $(i,j)$ is balanced if and only if $(i',j)$ is balanced, for $F_{n+1} < i,i' < F_{n+2}$ and $j \geq F_{n-1}$. ((b)) $(F_{n+1} + i,j)$ is balanced if and only if $(F_{n+2} -i, j)$ is balanced, for $1 \leq i < F_n$ and $j \geq 1$.

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: Suppose $F_i < m \leq F_{i+1}$. Then for all $n\geq 1$ there exists $j$, $1 \leq j \leq F_{i+1}$, such that $(m,n+j)$ is balanced. Furthermore the upper bound $F_{i+1}$ is optimal for each $m$.

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: The automaton in Figure~\ref{fig1} solves the balanced property for Fibonacci word rectangles. \label{fibb}

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: If $\max(m,n)$ is a Fibonacci number then the $m \times n$ matrices of ${\cal A}_{\gamma}$ are balanced.

title: Balanced Fibonacci word rectangles, and beyond
theorem_statement: The number of distinct values of $T(i, F_{3n}/2, F_{3n}/2)$ is $\Theta(n)$.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: Let $S\in {\rm sPerf}_C$. \item {\rm(Enriched fully-faithfulness)} The canonical functor from Vector Spaces to Topological Vector Spaces  \[ \R\pi_*: \sd(S_{\proeet},\Q_p)\to \underline{\sd}(S,\Q_p) \]  tends to be fully faithful. More precisely, let $\sff\in \sd^b(S_{\proeet},\Q_p)$ be such that $\R\pi_*\sff\in \underline{\sd}^b(S,\Q_p)$ and let $\sg\in \sd^+(S_{\proeet},\Q_p)$. Then the canonical morphism in $\underline{\sd}(S,\Q_p)$  \[ \R\pi_*\R\Hhom_{S}(\sff,\sg)\to \R\Hhom_{S^{\rm top}}(\R\pi_*\sff,\R\pi_*\sg) \]  is a quasi-isomorphism. \item {\rm(Fargues-Fontaine fully-faithfulness)} The functor  \[ \R\tau_*: {\rm QCoh}(X_{\FF, S^{\flat}})\to \underline{\sd}(S,\Q_{p}) \]  is fully faithful when restricted to perfect complexes. That is, for $\sff,\sg\in {\rm Perf}(X_{\FF, S^{\flat}})$, the natural map in ${\sd}({\rm Mod}^{\rm cond}_{\underline{\Q}_p(S)})$  \[ \R\Hom_{{\rm QCoh}(X_{\FF,S^{\flat}})}(\sff,\sg)\to \R\uHom_{S,\Q_{p}}(\R\tau_*\sff,\R\tau_*\sg) \]  is a quasi-isomorphism. \item {\rm (Compatibility of the algebraic and topological projections)} The functor  \[ \R\tau^{\prime}_*: {\rm QCoh}(X_{\FF, S^{\flat}})\to {\sd}(S_{\proeet},\Q_{p}) \]  is compatible with the functor $\R\tau_*$ when restricted to nuclear sheaves. That is, the following diagram commutes  \[ \xymatrix{ {\rm Nuc}(X_{\FF,S^{\flat}})\ar[r]^-{\R\tau^{\prime}_*}\ar[rd]^{\R\tau_*} & \sd(S_{\proeet},{\Q}_p)\ar[d]^{\R\pi_*} & \underline{\sd}(S,{\Q}_p). } \]

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: {\rm(Enriched fully-faithfulness)} \label{duck1} Let $\sff\in \sd^b(S_{\proeet},{\rm Ab})$ be such that $\R\pi_*\sff\in \underline{\sd}^b(S,{\rm CondAb})_0$ and let $\sg\in \sd^+(S_{\proeet},{\rm Ab})$. The canonical morphism in $\underline{\sd}(S,{\rm CondAb})$  \[ \label{faith10-1} \R\pi_*\R\Hhom_{S}(\sff,\sg)\to \R\Hhom_{S^{\rm top}}(\R\pi_*\sff,\R\pi_*\sg) \]  is a quasi-isomorphism. We have analogous claims for $\underline{\Q}_p$-sheaves.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: \label{acyclic1} Let $\sff\in\{\underline{\Q}_p, {\mathbb G}_a, \mathbb{B}^+_{\dr}/t^i, \mathbb{B}^{+,\phi=p^i}_{\crr}\}$ be a sheaf on $S_{\proeet}$. We have $\R^i\pi_*\sff=0$, for $i>0$. In particular, we have a natural quasi-isomorphism $\pi_*\sff\stackrel{\sim}{\to} \R\pi_*\sff$ in $\sd(S_{\proeet},{\rm CondAb})$.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: \label{koczkodan2} The set \eqref{pierre10} for $w$-contractible $Y$'s and extremally disconnected $T$'s generates ${\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},{\rm CondAb})$. Moreover, these generators are compact and projective.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement:
\label{solidification1} The canonical forgetful functor ${\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},{\rm Solid})\to {\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},{\rm CondAb})$ is
(topologically) fully faithful and has a
(topological) left adjoint $\sff\mapsto \sff^{\Box}$ given by the sheafification of the presheaf\footnote{The sheafification is necessary because the solidification functor $\Box$ is not left exact.}:  \[ {\sff}^{\Box,{\rm psh}}:\quad \{Y\mapsto \sff(Y)^{\Box}\},\quad Y\in S_{\proeet}. \]  It commutes with all colimits.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: \label{adj1}If $\sff_1,\sff_2,\sff_3\in {\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},{\rm Solid})$, there is a canonical functorial isomorphism in ${\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},{\rm Solid})$  \[ \Hhom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_1\otimes^{\Box}\sff_2,\sff_3)\stackrel{\sim}{\to} \Hhom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_1,\Hhom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_2,\sff_3)). \]  In particular, we have a canonical functorial isomorphism in ${\rm Solid}$  \[ \Hom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_1\otimes^{\Box}\sff_2,\sff_3)\simeq \Hom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_1,\Hhom^{\Box}_{S}(\sff_2,\sff_3)). \]

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: \label{Gro1} The category ${\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},\underline{\Q}_{p,\Box})$ is a Grothendieck abelian category.

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement: \label{kaczka20} If $\sff_1,\sff_2,\sff_3\in {\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},\underline{\Q}_{p,\Box})$, there is a canonical functorial isomorphism in ${\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet},\underline{\Q}_{p,\Box})$  \[ \Hhom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_1\otimes^{\Box}_{\underline{\Q}_p}\sff_2, \sff_3)\stackrel{\sim}{\to} \Hhom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_1,\Hhom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_2, \sff_3)). \]  In particular, we have a canonical functorial isomorphism in ${\rm Mod}^{\rm solid}_{\Q_p(S)}$  \[ \uHom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_1\otimes^{\Box}_{\underline{\Q}_p}\sff_2, \sff_3)\simeq \uHom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_1,\Hhom^{\Box}_{S,\underline{\Q}_{p}}(\sff_2, \sff_3)). \]

title: Topological Vector Spaces
theorem_statement:
\label{form23} Let $W\in \Q_{p,\Box}$ be a Fr\'echet or of compact type. Let $\sff\in {\rm Sh}(S_{\proeet}, \underline{\Q}_{p,\Box} )$.
(There) is a canonical quasi-isomorphism in $\sd(S_{\proeet},\Q_{p,\Box})$  \[ \label{form11-1} W\otimes^{\LL_{\Box}}_{\Q_{p}}\sff\stackrel{\sim}{\to} \underline{W}\otimes^{\LL_{\Box}}_{\Q_{p}}\sff. \]
(There) is a natural isomorphism in $\Q_{p,\Box}$  \[ \uHom^{\Box}_{S,\Q_p}(\underline{W} ,\sff) \stackrel{\sim}{\to} \uHom^{\Box}_{ \Q_p} (W,\sff(S)). \]
(There) is a natural quasi-isomorphism in $\sd(\Q_{p,\Box})$  \[ \R\uHom^{\Box}_{S,\Q_p}(\underline{W},\sff) \simeq \R\uHom_{\Q_{p,\Box}} (W,\R\Gamma(S^{\rm top}_{\proeet},\sff)). \]
(If) $W$ is of compact type then there is a natural quasi-isomorphism in $\sd(\Q_{p,\Box})$  \[ \R\uHom^{\Box}_{S,\Q_p}(\underline{W},\sff) \simeq W^*\otimes^{\LL_{\Box}}_{\Q_p}\R\Gamma(S^{\rm top}_{\proeet},\sff). \]

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm:introextension} Let $X$ be either a Shimura variety or a geometric period image with torsion-free level structure. There exists an integer $N$ with the following property. Let $p$ be a prime that doesn't divide $N$ and suppose $F$ is a discretely valued $p$-adic field containing the field of definition of $X$. Suppose that $f: (\Dstar)^a \times \sD^b \rightarrow X_F^{\an}$ is a rigid-analytic map defined over $F$ such that $\Im(f)$ intersects the good-reduction locus of $X_F$. Then, $f$ extends to a map $\sD^{a+b} \rightarrow X_F^\an$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm:introalgebraicity} Let $X,p$ and $F$ be as above, and let $M$ be an algebraic variety defined over $F$. Then, every rigid-analytic map $f: M^{\an} \rightarrow X^\an$ defined over $F$ such that $\Im(f)$ is contained in the good reduction locus is the analytification of an algebraic map $M \rightarrow X$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement:
\label{thm: Brunebarbe} Let $\mathscr{X}$ be a smooth scheme over $W(\Fpbar)$, and let $\mathscr{X}^{\rig}$ denote its rigid generic fiber. Let $\bL/\mathscr{X}^{\rig}$ be a crystalline local system with $\VFL$ the associated Fontaine-Laffaile module. Suppose that we are in one of the following two cases.
(The) Kodaira-Spencer map associated to the filtered flat bundle underlying $\VFL$ is everywhere immersive.
(The) Griffiths bundle associated to $\VFL$ is an ample bundle on $\mathscr{X}$. Then, every map $(\Dstar)^{a} \times \sD^b \rightarrow \mathscr{X}^{\rig}$ extends to a map $\sD^{a+b}\rightarrow \mathscr{X}^{\rig}$

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm: all good or all bad} Let $f : \Dstar \rightarrow X^\an$ be an analytic map where $X$ is as above. Then either $f(\Dstar) \subseteq X^{\good}$ or $f(\Dstar) \subseteq (X^\an \setminus X^{\good})$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm:prismatic_F_crystals_and_local_systems} Let $\fX/\mO_K$ be a smooth $p$-adic formal scheme. There is a natural equivalence of categories \[ \Vect^{\textup{an}, \varphi} (\fX_{\Prism}) \isom \textup{Loc}^{\textup{crys}}_{\Z_p}(\fX_{\eta}). \] In particular, this equivalence is functorial in $\fX$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{prop:existence_of_crystal} Assume the above setup. Up to replacing $\sD$ by a smaller closed disc in $\sD$ if necessary, there exists an $F$-crystal $\mathbb D$ over $\A^1$ with $\mathbb D [1/p] \cong \mathbb E$, that is compatible with the crystalline $\Z_p$-local system $\mathbb L$ in the following sense: for every finite extension $L/K$ and every classical $L$-point $x \in \sD$ which specializes to a closed point $\overline{x} \in \A^1$, there is an isomorphism $\mathbb D|_{\overline{x}} \cong \mathbb D_{\textup{crys}} (\mathbb L|_{x})$ of $F$-crystals over $\overline{x}$. Consequently, up to replacing $\sD$ by a smaller disc, the isomorphism class of the $F$-crystal $\mathbb{D}_{\textup{cris}}(\bL_x)$ is independent of the classical point $x\in \sD$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm: constancy of F-crystal} Let $X$ be a smooth connected variety over $\Fpbar$. Let $\D /X$ be a point-wise constant $F$-crystal such that the $F$-isocrystal $\D[1/p]$ is constant. Then $\D$ itself is constant.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \label{thm: crystalline extension} Let $\bL/\Dstar$ be a $\Z_p$-local system with crystalline fibers everywhere. Then, $\bL$ extends to a crystalline local system on $\sD$.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \Cref{thm:introextension} is true for $a=1,b=0$ and $X$ a Shimura variety.

title: $p$-adic hypoerbolicity for Shimura varieties and period images
theorem_statement: \Cref{thm:introextension} is true for $a=1,b=0$ and $X$ a geometric period image.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \label{theorem: genus_le_2} There are exactly $3711$ Shimura curves quotients $X_0^D(N)/W$, with $D>1$ and with $W \leq W_0(D,N)$ a non-trivial subgroup, of genus at most $2$. In particular, there are \item $779$ curves $X_0^D(N)/W$ having genus $0$, \item $1352$ curves $X_0^D(N)/W$ having genus $1$, and \item $1580$ curves $X_0^D(N)/W$ having genus $2$.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement:
\label{theorem: iso_classes_thm_intro} Let $X = X_0^D(N)/W$ be a genus $1$ curve with $W \leq W_0(D,N)$ a non-trivial Atkin--Lehner subgroup.
(If) $X$ is among the $1270$ such curves with $N$ squarefree, then the isomorphism class of $\Jac(X)$ is as given in \cref{table: genus_1_sqfree_iso_classes}.
(If) $X$ is among the $82$ such curves with $N$ not squarefree, then the isogeny class of $\Jac(X)$ is as given in \cref{table: genus_1_not_sqfree_isog_classes}.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \cite[Theorem 0]{Sh75}\label{thm: no_real_points} If $D>1$, then $X_0^D(N)(\R) = \emptyset$.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \cite{Ribet90, BD96, HPS89a, HPS89b}\label{Ribet_isog} There is an isogeny defined over $\Q$ \[ \Psi \colon \Jac(X_0(DN))^{D-\new} \longrightarrow \Jac(X_0^D(N)) \] such that, for each Atkin--Lehner involution $w_m(D,N) \in W_0(D,N)$, the corresponding automorphism $\Psi^*(w_m(D,N))$ on $\Jac(X_0(DN))^{D-\textnormal{new}}$ is  \[ \label{eqn: AL_action_Ribet} \Psi^*(w_m(D,N)) = (-1)^{\omega(\gcd(D,m))}w_m(1,DN), \]  where $w_m(1,DN) \in W_0(1,DN)$ denotes the Atkin--Lehner involution corresponding to $m$ on the modular curve $X_0(DN)$.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \label{theorem: CD_uniformization} Let $D$ be the discriminant of an indefinite quaternion algebra over $\Q$, let $N$ be a squarefree positive integer with $\gcd(D,N) = 1$, and let $p \mid D$ be a prime. Let $W \leq W_0(D,N)$ be an Atkin--Lehner subgroup, and let $G_W$ be as defined above. Then the Atkin--Lehner quotient $X_0^D(N)/W$ over $\Z_p$ is a Mumford curve (c.f. \cite{Mumford}), and the dual graph of its special fiber is given by $\widetilde{G_W^*}$ with $w_p$ inducing the Frobenius automorphism.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: {\cite[Theorem 1.1]{Abramovich96}} \label{theorem: Abr} For the Shimura curve $X_0^D(N)$, we have \[ \gamma_{\C}(X_0^D(N)) \ge \frac{975}{8192}\big(g(X_0^D(N))-1\big). \]

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement:
\cite[Theorem 5.4 (1),(2),(4)]{DD15}\label{Dokchitser_thm} Let $\varphi: E \to E'$ be an isogeny of elliptic curves over $\Q_p$ of prime degree $\ell$.
(If) $E$ has potentially good reduction and $p \ne \ell$, then the Kodaira types of $E$ and $E'$ are the same.
(If) $E$ has potentially good ordinary reduction and $p = \ell$, then the Kodaira types of $E$ and $E'$ are the same.
(If) $E$ has multiplicative reduction, with Kodaira type $I_n$ for $E$, then $E'$ has Kodaira type either $I_{pn}$ or $I_{n/p}$ corresponding to $v(j') = pv(j)$ and $pv(j')=v(j)$, respectively.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \label{theorem: genus_one_jacobian_isomorphism_classes} Let $X = X_0^D(N)/W$ be a genus $1$ Atkin--Lehner quotient with $W \leq W_0(D,N)$ non-trivial and $N$ squarefree. Then $\Jac(X)$ is isomorphic over $\Q$ to the elliptic curve with Cremona reference given in \cref{table: genus_1_sqfree_iso_classes}.

title: Shimura curve Atkin--Lehner quotients of genus at most two
theorem_statement: \label{theorem: non-elliptic_genus_one_equations} Each of the curves $X = X_0^D(N)/W$ listed in \cref{table: non_elliptic_eqns} is non-elliptic of genus $1$. For the $4$ triples $(D,N,W)$ in the set \begin{align*} \Big\{ &\left(14, 11, \langle w_2, w_{11} \rangle \right), \left(46, 3, \langle w_2, w_3 \rangle \right), &\left(570, 1, \langle w_5, w_{57} \rangle \right), \left(570, 1, \langle w_6, w_{190} \rangle\right) \Big\}, \end{align*} the curve $X$ admits exactly one of the two models given in \cref{table: non_elliptic_eqns} over $\Q$. Each of the remaining $146$ curves $X$ in \cref{table: non_elliptic_eqns} admits the given model over $\Q$.
